story:
Our Story

We stand firm in our belief that healthy food shouldn’t taste like cardboard, and that delicious, opulent, indulgent food shouldn’t have poisonous ingredients. We infuse every ingredient, step in the process and the end product with reiki, to enhance the real sacredness of chocolate: the here and now moment of enjoyment where grace is present and healing occurs. 

Our daughter Olivia (6) who showed us a healthy way to enjoy decadence. 

We found out the hard way that sugar and toxic chemicals in the environment can plunge a child's experience into darkness. In early January 2017 our first-born daughter Olivia was suffering from excruciating tummy aches, nightmares, troubled thoughts and a stutter. It turned out sugar, petrochemicals and pollution were the culprits! We quickly removed these poisons from our bodies and environment and turned to essential oils, and her relief swept through our family like a wave of Grace. But that meant no chocolate!!! At least, no store bought, cheap, toxic candy. Her father Matthew studied, practiced, meditated, and came up with the unparalleled Red Wagon recipe. We tried it out - and it worked! 

Within a few months the chocolate had two celebrity endorsements - celebrity chef Craig Chasky and fullback Heath Evans (representing his line of health food) both sampled and showcased the chocolates! To ensure safe doses of essential oils and the highest benefits from each ingredient, we secured the thumbs up from an award-winning nutritionist. 

But just as we started receiving the first steady orders of chocolate, Hurricane Irma did her thing and Matthew was laid off. This displaced our family to Conifer, Colorado, where we were able to live thanks to the loving generosity of a dear friend.

Olivia, Penelope and Rylan Tymerson - who took us in and opened his home to us. The cabin now also serves as a destination for healing retreats and chocolate making! 

A blessing in disguise! Not only have our daughters benefited immensely from the clean mountain air, but the community has welcomed us with open arms and showed phenomenal support for our chocolates! Within less than two months the chocolates are selling in five stores, and we have a bustling online shop and Facebook group. We host mountain view healing events at the cabin and share the art of chocolate, teaching our neighbors the process of conscious chocolate making, teaching the benefits of plant energy, and teaching the art of reiki as an ingredient. Our girls are homeschooled in the forest and the family is thriving! 

A homeschool project that helps the family business: Boxing and labeling teaches us focus, discipline, precision, trade, business, communication, exchange, marketing, design, and we get to spend some real quality time together knowing we are doing our bit for the world.

 

Our Vision

We want to open a healing chocolate factory here in the mountains:

  • If we have an open, commercial grade kitchen we can demonstrate the art of chocolate and teach the next generation of conscious candy makers.
  • With a space for healings, meditations, and guest crafters we can enhance the multi-sensory nature of healing.
  • We can sell high quantities of high quality craft chocolate spreading the body, mind and spirit benefits even further, making a strong profit and contributing to our community, leaving a legacy for our little daughters.
  • Your contribution will go directly to building this unique business model and making Conifer, Colorado a destination for high end chocolate healing retreats. 

You know what we love most about Conifer? Other than our family's health and happiness?

What about that moment when a snow cloud moves through the valley as we stand on the deck where we offer healing chocolate retreats, and for a moment we're suspended alongside the snowflakes - they aren't falling, we're just hanging here together, twinkling. A moment of poise - neither up nor down. Each one unique, its purpose and place perfectly etched into the moment. And each of them reflecting its own glimmer of the sun, its specific position amongst all the others creating that one spark that adds to a symphony of light. 

The view from the Red Wagon chocolate cabin.

Or maybe when the day just weighs heavy on the soul, not for any good reason, when the 23 things to worry about shout louder than the billion things to rejoice over, and we step outside to remind us why we're here and THESE souls come to greet us. 

Shy but curious wild mule deer. 

But why is healing so important to us? Why not just make chocolate?

Because we believe that at the core of every soul’s purpose is the call to heal, elevate, nurture and illuminate all around us. Healing is simply “to make whole”, and by being the best we can be we are in great service to the world:

  • We can heal directly, by studying the healing gifts of nature and creating healing remedies in the form of indulgent treats (enjoyment is very healing indeed).
  • We can cook healing chocolate and study nutrition and understand our bodies. We can understand the mind, psychology and critical thinking so we can better teach the power of alignment and choice.
  • We can study energy and the use of energy systems to affect change in the mind, body and spirit by using reiki, qi gong or prayer (which is a word we use for focused applied thought or intention).
  • We can heal through service to others, by engaging in our community and sharing our abundance with worthy causes that mean a lot to our customers and to us.
  • We can heal by conducting our business ethically, teaching our children about trade and communication, politics and civics, so that they can be a part of building a moral and ethical future.

We believe that by creating a space to embody these healing principles as a fundamental part of the chocolate making process, and by sharing that space with all who desire a multi-sensory experience of enjoyment and delight, we will be serving at our highest. 

Elizabeth and Olivia on the deck of the chocolate cabin right before tucking into a steaming mug of Red Wagon cacao.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to get started. We're not looking to raise the full cost at first, but just enough to get our business pumping so we can earn what we need to bring our vision to Conifer, Colorado. 

  • We are operating successfully out of a cottage kitchen, but the restrictions of the cottage kitchen laws means we can't sell to grocery stores or restaurants. The current production cost per unit is $0.64 and each unit wholesales at $5 and retails at $8. At our current rate of production we can comfortably produce 1,600 units per month. In our first month operating in Conifer we sold 50 units, in the second month we sold 408, and we are projecting to sell in excess of 1,200 in March. 
  • By incorporating a commercial kitchen into the cabin we can triple production without compromising on the quality that is so important to us. Current restrictions in production are not enough molds or refrigeration space, which means if we could solve those we could triple production without having to add staffing costs.
  • We grow our sales and earn the rest of the capital we need much quicker. We have been quoted $35,000 for this, but by using salvaged and recycled materials and doing as much as we can ourselves and with friends and neighbors, we are budgeting $10,000 for the first round of commercial kitchen updates, and we'll work to earn the rest over time as we grow.  
  • We are budgeting $4000 for the architectural drawings, legal fees and county application fees to approve the cabin for mixed use. 
  • We currently market by social media, word of mouth and by engaging in the community and sharing our skills. We would do a passionate marketing push worldwide to attract visitors to the area and use chocolate as our vehicle for healing. We have been quoted some sky high prices for a marketing campaign but we know we could spend $1000 with local marketers, as well as connecting with other businesses for a holistic, encompassing approach to sharing the message. 
  • We're keeping a $5000 budget for Indigogo platform fees, taxes and contingency, and the production and shipping of perks. Any funds left over that don't go into these areas will be channeled into growing the business. 

Peace: An exquisite blend of lavender and valerian folded into velvety dark chocolate to soothe an agitated mind, calm energies and prepare the body for rest.

Your contributions will go straight to getting this unique business offering rolling! We have developed some delicious and exciting perks all designed so you can experience the deep and honest healing that comes with these vegan, gluten-free, no refined sugar treats!

For everyone able to make a smaller contribution, we've developed a special chocolate exclusive to Conifer and this campaign: Elevation - in honor of this magical mountain place we've put together pine, frankincense and lemon - the frequencies of these oils bring a crown tingling experience of opening, grounding and mountain air with every bite of luscious chocolate. We're also putting together a beautiful sampler pack with every one of our bestsellers including the exclusive Elevation. 

That beautiful shine comes from a perfect temper. 

For those able to contribute a little more, we're offering exclusive chocolate healing experiences at the mountain view cabin, where you get to learn the art of chocolate making, learn about the power of essential oils, create your own recipe based on your healing requirements and receive a reiki healing while your chocolate is setting, before you walk away with an entire batch of your special chocolate. 

The view from the chocolate cabin observation deck

The Risks

  • We might not raise all the money first time round...
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will still invest in growing the business but at a smaller level, so we can earn the remaining capital. We firmly believe we can meet our goal, but the more money we raise the more able we are to bring our vision of a healing chocolate factory to Conifer, Colorado! Building a business is challenging, but we are a strong, resilient, positive and happy family and we are deeply passionate about what we do. We'll keep going. 

The Red Wagon family: Matthew (40, master chocolatier), Elizabeth (36, healer), Olivia (6, Thank You card artist), Penelope (2, taste tester and mess maker)

The Impact

We are already making an impact on a personal and community level:

  • People who can't usually eat chocolate because of the high sugar content or intolerances to dairy are able to enjoy the multi-sensory delight this sacred treat brings. 
  • Testimonials of healing experiences keep coming and and we are humbled and delighted for each one! 
  • The community is enjoying craft-chocolate! 
  • With a sensible, strong and confident business approach we can have a significant impact on the local economy including harnessing a healthy cut from the tourism industry of neighboring areas. 

 

Our Customers

Our customers are our community and our family, whether near or far. We do this for you - because we love you and we see healing for you.

I am so happy to share how amazing Red Wagon Organic Chocolate and Elizabeth is! The first time I met Elizabeth she protected so much light and positivity that I knew I needed her in my life! I enjoyed the chocolates she brought to share even though I am not a chocolate lover at all. I was all to happy to experience their there night of chocolates! I had the pleasure of blending my much needed essential oils and CBC to my batch of chocolates! The rekie healing session was amazing! Elizabeth truly helped me let go and embrace some really difficult things that have been going on❤ Just having the energy of friendship with Elizabeth, Matthew and their amazing girls has made an impact in my families life❤ They are the real deal! Truly incredible people with nothing but light and love in their hearts!

Deanna Brown, Conifer, Colorado

Who knew chocolate could be this good...my new favorite is the Conifer Signature...with pine and frankincense...a close second is the Ignite (orange and frankincense). Healing oils in chocolate is brilliant! Nicely done!

Luna Mandala, Conifer, Colorado

I'm enjoying a taste of chocolate heaven,( infused with lavender, copaiba, & frankincense) while supervising my stubborn son to practice the piano. This chocolate is all the calming I need after a long work week & dealing with another sick kid. Thank you! #bestchocolatesever ????

Hilda Williamz, Conifer, Colorado

Conifer has a yogurt shop, ice cream shop, Natural Foods, and several restaurants and bars, but it does not have a chocolate shop. And what wonderful chocolate it is. No chocolate sold in the Conifer area even touches Red Wagon Organic Chocolates. We need this business here!

Julia Sheldon Morris

Matthew, I wish I could have made it home yesterday to check the mail, but the snow and ice had completely different plans. Your chocolate—absolutely incredible. I had a piece of the peppermint bar, and I was blown away. Truly. You can taste the quality of your craft. It had a beautiful mouth feel, and the decadence is enough to fulfill a craving for chocolate with even the smallest piece. The card was also a beautiful touch. I loved the artwork featured on the card! It truly shows the love your entire family puts into your craft, and makes things even more personal.

I think the most amazing part of this experience was the declaration of worth on the back of your pamphlet. This is something that I believe humans as a whole lose sight of, but it was also something that resonated so strongly with me personally. I have left a very toxic relationship with a powerful narcissist, and my feelings of self-worth definitely suffered. I’ve been working hard to reconnect to myself and my value, and to see this printed in the most unexpected of places was a beautiful reminder. I plan on hanging this on my fridge to offer that reminder anytime I’m struggling.

Your chocolates are healing, your words are healing, and today—I am thankful for you and Red Wagon. Thank you and your entire family for what you do.”

These chocolates, especially for someone who often feels as though commercial chocolate is far too sweet, are absolutely incredible. They are deep, rich, and absolutely phenomenal morsels of love and healing. Thank you for sharing these awesome gifts with us! ❤️

Jessica Ropke, New York

Hey guys. I had a healing session with Elizabeth at Red Wagon and it was so amazing! I haven’t even received the chocolates yet! Just the session was worth it! To get a session, a meditation, an evaluation on your chakras. Some mantras to work on and then chocolate specifically designed for you is just so powerful!

I cannot wait for the chocolate! ? It is so profound to have the healing aspect within the involvement of enjoying the appetites of the human experience.

Mind in processing what is holding your head space; Spirit in the healing session; Body in the act of eating and digesting the chocolates while the essential oils do their work in raising your frequencies. Then the masculine and feminine conduits who team up to make it all in one chocolate bar.

Thank you Holly for this gift! And thank you Red Wagon for your teamwork in bringing it all together.

Kate Karpel, St Petersburg, Florida

 Oh my? Not only is this good chocolate, but the reiki is strong, people... it is PUNGENT! And even further enhanced by essential oils and cocoa. I say it’s pure magic. I actually start and finish my day with a bite of Red Wagon ?Thank god it’s healthy! Can’t wait for the online event!!

Sylvia Swann, Oslo, Norway

 Wow, thank you Red Wagon Tribe. So you wanted to test out how successfully your healing chocolates would ship all the way to the UK! The answer is Perfectly! Thank you for using us as your guinea pigs, the pleasure was all ours! As someone who is mindful of what I put in both mine and my toddlers bodies, it is incredible to find something as indulgent as chocolate but without all the nasties. Even better, it replaces the nasties with pure and therapeutic ingredients. We sampled Ode to Love and Deep Dark and they were beautiful and a delight to savour every mouthful. True evidence that chocolate can be delicious, indulgent and nourish AND can be good for you. We loved them both.

The packaging was beautiful and simple. I loved your story of your journey that has lead to you creating such divine yumminess. It's an inspiration.

On another plus, because of the rich and pure ingredients your cravings are satisfied with just a small amount of chocolate ( this never usually happens for me), meaning you can savour every bite, and make it last longer. So much better for your health, mind and purse :). We can't wait to try more.

Kama Wager, Buckinghamshire, UK

 I want to share with you all my testimonial for these beautiful people. To quote Kahlil Gibrahn, Matthew and Elizabeth are certainly walking their "path with a heart". Their strength of purpose and honour in combining love and healing with pure divine chocolate, proving that delicious treats can come from simple, organic, natural ingredients without any of the nasties, is unrivaled. Their consciousness in their approach to nutrition and wellness as well as their love for their family and community is so wonderfully inspiring. You can't help but melt when you see their super cute and gorgeously happy chocolate covered girls! If ever there was a couple that deserved to achieve their dreams of spreading opulent deliciousness, love and healing in every one of their handcrafted organic chocolates, it is most certainly the beautiful spirits of Matthew and Elizabeth, Red Wagon Organic Chocolates! I wish you both so much love and light as you continue on this incredible soul path together. ???

 Tina Roberts, UK

To me self-healing is really important. Some people call it self love. I call it taking care and being compassionate towards yourself. I believe self healing starts at the roots; the food you eat, the air you breathe, and even thoughts you keep. I LOVE Red Wagon Organic Chocolates because you not only have healing organic ingredients including high grade essential oils, but they were crafted with a lot of LOVE from the start. I think these healing chocolates are an ingenious idea! I can't wait to see what other yummy healing chocolate combinations you come up with next!!!

 Mandy Handly, Florida

Just received my chocolate in the mail. Couldn't be more delicious! The dark chocolate peppermint melts in your mouth with no bitter after taste. Thank you, Matt and Elizabeth!

 Natalie Tibbets, Orlando, Florida

Matt and Elizabeth devote their lives to making the world a better place. They are conscious and intentional in all they are engaged in on every level: physical, emotional, mental and spiritual.

Rev. Dr. Suzi Schadle

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love great chocolate, you can also help us by spreading the word about our campaign. Please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and other social media and let everyone know we need their help. Indigogo has some cool share tools.

If you are able to help out in some other way, contribute a larger amount, or help supply equipment or materials for the space, please get in touch directly. We'd love to hear from you and are always open to exciting ideas and collaborations!

Thank you!

Our Story
We stand firm in our belief that healthy food shouldn’t taste like cardboard, and that delicious, opulent, indulgent food shouldn’t have poisonous ingredients. We infuse every ingredient, step in the process and the end product with reiki, to enhance the real sacredness of chocolate: the here and now moment of enjoyment where grace is present and healing occurs. 

Our daughter Olivia (6) who showed us a healthy way to enjoy decadence. 
We found out the hard way that sugar and toxic chemicals in the environment can plunge a child's experience into darkness. In early January 2017 our first-born daughter Olivia was suffering from excruciating tummy aches, nightmares, troubled thoughts and a stutter. It turned out sugar, petrochemicals and pollution were the culprits! We quickly removed these poisons from our bodies and environment and turned to essential oils, and her relief swept through our family like a wave of Grace. But that meant no chocolate!!! At least, no store bought, cheap, toxic candy. Her father Matthew studied, practiced, meditated, and came up with the unparalleled Red Wagon recipe. We tried it out - and it worked!

To ensure safe doses of essential oils and the highest benefits from each ingredient, we secured the thumbs up from an award-winning nutritionist. 
But just as we started receiving the first steady orders of chocolate, Hurricane Irma did her thing and Matthew was laid off. This displaced our family to Conifer, Colorado, where we were able to live thanks to the loving generosity of a dear friend.

Olivia, Penelope and Rylan Tymerson - who took us in and opened his home to us. The cabin now also serves as a destination for healing retreats and chocolate making! 
A blessing in disguise! Not only have our daughters benefited immensely from the clean mountain air, but the community has welcomed us with open arms and showed phenomenal support for our chocolates! Within less than two months the chocolates are selling in five stores, and we have a bustling online shop and Facebook group. Shy but curious wild mule deer.

Because we believe that at the core of every soul’s purpose is the call to heal, elevate, nurture and illuminate all around us. Healing is simply “to make whole”, and by being the best we can be we are in great service to the world:

We can heal directly, by studying the healing gifts of nature and creating healing remedies in the form of indulgent treats (enjoyment is very healing indeed).

We can heal through service to others, by engaging in our community and sharing our abundance with worthy causes that mean a lot to our customers and to us.
We can heal by conducting our business ethically, teaching our children about trade and communication, politics and civics, so that they can be a part of building a moral and ethical future.

 I want to share with you all my testimonial for these beautiful people. To quote Kahlil Gibrahn, Matthew and Elizabeth are certainly walking their "path with a heart". Their strength of purpose and honour in combining love and healing with pure divine chocolate, proving that delicious treats can come from simple, organic, natural ingredients without any of the nasties, is unrivaled. Their consciousness in their approach to nutrition and wellness as well as their love for their family and community is so wonderfully inspiring. You can't help but melt when you see their super cute and gorgeously happy chocolate covered girls! If ever there was a couple that deserved to achieve their dreams of spreading opulent deliciousness, love and healing in every one of their handcrafted organic chocolates, it is most certainly the beautiful spirits of Matthew and Elizabeth, Red Wagon Organic Chocolates! I wish you both so much love and light as you continue on this incredible soul path together. ???
 Tina Roberts, UK
To me self-healing is really important. Some people call it self love. I call it taking care and being compassionate towards yourself. I believe self healing starts at the roots; the food you eat, the air you breathe, and even thoughts you keep. I LOVE Red Wagon Organic Chocolates because you not only have healing organic ingredients including high grade essential oils, but they were crafted with a lot of LOVE from the start. I think these healing chocolates are an ingenious idea! I can't wait to see what other yummy healing chocolate combinations you come up with next!!!
 Mandy Handly, Florida
Just received my chocolate in the mail. Couldn't be more delicious! The dark chocolate peppermint melts in your mouth with no bitter after taste. Thank you, Matt and Elizabeth!
 Natalie Tibbets, Orlando, Florida
Matt and Elizabeth devote their lives to making the world a better place. They are conscious and intentional in all they are engaged in on every level: physical, emotional, mental and spiritual.
Rev. Dr. Suzi Schadle


 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you love great chocolate, you can also help us by spreading the word about our campaign. Please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and other social media and let everyone know we need their help. Indigogo has some cool share tools.
If you are able to help out in some other way, contribute a larger amount, or help supply equipment or materials for the space, please get in touch directly. We'd love to hear from you and are always open to exciting ideas and collaborations!
Thank you!

story:
Overview

More and more people have become aware of the problems that single-use plastic straws bring and they have started switching to better alternatives, such as metal, silicone, and bamboo!

Although they help to reduce the waste in our environment, we’ve realized that they raise problems of their own. Current alternative straws are unsanitary and difficult to clean. That’s why our team here at WonderSip created a revolutionary straw that is reusable and super convenient to clean.

With our WonderSip straws, there’s no need to wonder about what kind of germs are living inside of your reusable straw.

 

 

 

Problems with Current Alternative Straws 

Although current reusable straws help to combat the huge single-use plastic waste problem, they contain their own complications. Many alternatives have a weird taste & texture that makes drinking not fun! Who said saving the planet would leave a bad taste in your mouth? 

Not only do these alternatives suck, they're basically hard to clean! The inside of straws are a breeding ground for nasty, hidden germs who thrive in dark, moist places. Without having a way to clean the inside effectively (let's face it, pipe cleaners are not the best tools to clean the inside of these thin straws), these germs grow and multiply! And guess what happens when you decide to take a sip of your favorite drink with your moldy, contaminated reusable straw? What's even worse is that you can't see what's going on inside the straw. Sorry, you're not invited to this party. 

 

Our Solution

So, what's our solution to this? The solution is simple: introducing WonderSip, the world’s first reusable straw created with One-Click Open technology for effective cleaning, crafted in a One-Piece Design.

 

Convenient To Clean

Cleaning has never been easier with our WonderSip straw. With our One-Click Open technology, you can effectively clean your straw in various ways without worrying about any nasty hidden surprises. So, how do you clean it? It's simple, ready? 

  • Wash It - With our One-Click Open technology, simply click it open and wash it under warm water and soap!
  • Rinse/Wipe It - Who really has the time to go to the public bathroom to clean their reusable straw with a pipe cleaner? If you're on the go and don't have time to clean it right away, just rinse/wipe it and store it away for later!
  • Put it in the Dishwasher - Just click it open and throw it in the dishwasher to clean. No extra steps necessary, or needed.

 

Preorder Your WonderSip NOW

Make WonderSip part of your everyday routine! Our WonderSip straws come in different styles, sizes, and colors.  Now it's a straw partaaay! Bring your friends ;)

 

 

Sustainable Packaging

We have designed our WonderSip Reusable Carrying Pouch through sustainable methods to reduce our carbon footprint. Each pouch is designed from premium linen fiber, which is eco-friendly, biodegradable, durable, anti-bacterial, and water resistant. 

 

Rewards

 

Thank you for being a part of our WonderSip community. Please help us spread the love to all of your friends/family. Let’s reduce plastic in our oceans and #SipHappilyEverAfter.  

 

For wholesale opportunities, please contact us at click@wondersip.com

story:
Map of vegetation restoration and absorption of CO2 in animal grazing grasslands and feed fields

 

 ORGANIC VEGAN:     

     Introducing Tasty And Nutritious  Organic Vegan Snacks and  Rice Syrup 

     

OUR STORY 

  When the meat dairy production in Large-scale land, 83% of farmland worldwide makes vegetation restoration, absorption of CO2 should be incredible. 

Greenhouse gas reduction effect through improvement of global food system.

 

  Traditional conservation methods are also necessary, such as designating new protected areas and preparing regulations to rescue specific species, but to save nature at the global level, we ultimately need to change the way we eat and produce it.

  We should change our diet to vegetarian food or vegan and reduce demand for meat or dairy products and restores the land used to produce them.

   Thereby absorbing CO2 and reducing global temperature.  CO2 emissions must be reduced by 45% in order to reduce global temperature by 1.5 degrees. 

Vegan uses only 50% carbon, 1/11 oil, 1/13 water and 7/18 soil compared to meat.

A vegetarian diet to breathe global warming.

  In conclusion, the link between vegetarianism and veganism is directly linked to forest and ecosystem restoration and short-term greenhouse gas reduction, which can lead to significant time gains toward a low-carbon energy system that reaches its critical point.

Organic products are invaluable.   The importance of this method of farming constantly sounded in certain term.   Our environment is dependent on the way our foods are grown.

Scientists on Climate Change Countermeasure Committee  Say Organic Vegan Products are the Shortcut to Restoring the Global Environment.  The Paris Climate Agreement signed and various voices responding to climate attacks are a global trend.   Many diseases also emerged from a contaminated global environment.   The Practice of Organic Vegan is the shortcut to saving the planet Earth.

$20 will be donated for Climate Change Countermeasure when you order Early Bird 2 Set Special Perk.

Increased greenhouse gas emission (the major cause of global warming - a discussion for another day), soil erosion, water pollution, and a threat to human health, has been proven to be the dividends of the conventional farming method.   On the other hand, Organic farming tends to be better for the environment.   This farming method has rewarded us with reduced pollution, increased soil fertility, and a replenished natural ecosystem for more clean air and water amidst others.

However, despite the excelling value of organic farming over its counterpart, it only makes up a small share of the United States  farming.   According to data by the National Agricultural statistics service, as of 2016, there were about 5 million certified organic farmland, which is less than 1% of the 910 million acres of farmland across the country.   According to recent industry statistics (Nutrition Business Journal), organic products account for only about 4 percent (4%) of the total U.S. food sales.

As far as we are concerned, it is not fair enough, we believe there should be a better way.   We thought of Organic Vegan Corporation.

 

OUR COMPANY

Organic Vegan Corporation   is a Korea Agricultural Corporation established the year 2010, to save humanity and the earth and spread the distribution, cultivation, and consumption of organic products.   It is a way of protecting the earth beyond the value of health and making use of the land as an organic field. 

“Deul Haneul”, which means, “field and sky” is the brand name for all our healthily grown organic products - that is products produced without the use of pesticides, chemical fertilizers, and herbicides.

Because meeting the needs for healthy food is at the heart of our products, it gladdens our heart to see our products being at the receiving end of stupendous international recognition over the past two years.

The time has now come to add to our products gallery. This time, we will be drafting two organic vegan snacks and an organic rice syrup into the mix.

 

Organic Brown Rice Cereal Snack (Non-Sweet Puff)

This naturally flavored organic vegan puff snack is made of organic brown rice. Because this rice grown organically – without fertilizer and agricultural chemicals, the puff is naturally flavored, with natural taste and texture.

 

Ingredients

Why you’ll love it

  • 100% organic without artificial additives
  • Sugar-free, Organic, Vegan, Gluten Free
  • Rich flavor and soft texture
  • Good for all ages

 

Organic Brown Rice Cereal Snack (Sweet Puff)

Similar to the non- sweet puff, it is made of organic brown rice only with the addition of organic rice syrup - a syrup made from organic rice and barley malt powder.

Ingredients

Why you’ll love it

  • Sweet and Tasty snack
  • No artificial flavor, Organic, Vegan
  • Good for all age

 

Organic Rice Syrup

With sprouted organic rice and malt powder, we employ the use of traditional food processing methods to make this organic rice syrup.

Why you’ll love it

  • A healthy substitute for sugar
  • An organic sweetener
  • Sugar-free
  • Additive-free

What is more

All these three newly introduced products are not only USDA certified  but also HACCP-ISO 2200 certified - the best you can get as far as the organic product is concerned.   You can comfortably consume these tasty and highly nutritious snacks knowing fully well that you are consuming 100% organic products.

WHERE YOU COME IN

Considering the benefits of organic products, our greatest desire is to turn the whole world into vegan. That is why in recent years, our focus has shifted to providing organic processed products to overseas countries. We aim to continue on this quest with the introduction of these new snacks and syrup.   However with all new ideas, this we can not do on our own, we know for sure that your support will be needed to breathe life into this new initiative and we’re hanging on that.

When we do our cost, about $3250  needed to transmute this idea into reality.   So we feel like giving you the opportunity to raise the fund together.  To show our appreciation for your genuine support, we’ve created an amazing reward structure specifically designed with you in mind. Kindly select any one of your choices at the right corner of your screen and pledge your support.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

We get it, some of you might not be able to contribute financially to this campaign because of one reason or the other.   Don’t worry, we can understand however you can still be part of our family and lend your support by:

  • Giving us constructive suggestions
  • Informing your friends and family about veganism and this campaign
  • Sharing this across all your social media pages (awareness is as important as every penny)
  • Buying our products when we finally launch

Thank you for stopping by to read our story.   We are also grateful for your support both in cash and kind, you never know how much it means to us.   We trust that with your help, we’ll be able to mass-produce all these products.

Once again, thank you.

story:
In 1980, our parents emigrated from Cambodia as refugees fleeing the Khmer Rouge genocide.  In 1987, they opened Phnom Penh Noodle House.  As the only Cambodian restaurant in Seattle, Phnom Penh was the cultural hub of the Cambodian community in greater Seattle and beyond for more than 30 years. 

Our parents passed the restaurant down to us 3 sisters when they retired.  Unfortunately, due to a family tragedy, we decided to close the business in May, 2018.  Dawn’s son, Devin was hit by a car and suffered severe traumatic brain injuries.   He was a senior at Franklin High School and an ultimate frisbee superstar!  We needed to step away to focus on our families, heal, and help Dawn, Devin, and her other 2 kiddos transition to this new way of life.

It’s been an incredibly difficult 2 years.  Devin still has a long road to recovery and we're still adjusting, but we're in a much better spot.  Mainly due to the love, support, and words of encouragement from this community.    

It's because of YOU and the help of community efforts & resources, that we’re on track to            re-open the restaurant! 

We are oh-so-close, but we need a little more help.  Build-out costs are proliferating.  We need to raise additional funds to complete construction and get us to grand opening!  

Help us raise the funds so we can focus our energies on getting the restaurant up and running as quickly as possible, because we've missed you and can't wait to serve your favorite dish again!

Please help us spread the word so that we may reach our goal!  Share our campaign with family and friends.

 

Hugs,

Dawn, Diane, & Darlene

story:
There is an increasing demand for healthy food selections and a significantly low number of fresh food eateries available to serve the public's growing appetite.(According to the Organic Trade Association.)

Blackburn's Farm to Table expects to fill that void by establishing relationships with local growers, offering support and help to grow the community, creating jobs within our eatery and by supporting local merchants by using their services.

Blackburn's will also host events and increase Farm to Table awareness.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is the break down in more detail:

  • We currently operate a fully functional commercial kitchen in Corona and we're seeking help for dining and restroom improvements. We also need to purchase small wares including a commercial dishwasher.
  • We're offering breakfast, lunch and private dinners based on your donations.
  • If we do not reach our goal we will make improvements based on what we receive and continue to build-out and work towards opening Blackburn's Farm to Table.

The Impact

Local Support - We'll offer fresh and healthy seasonal menus based on produce, dairy and meats sourced from local food growers and markets along with sustainable seafood.

Health Awareness - We'll encourage overall awareness and interest in healthy, fresh and creative eating.

Experience - We are professionally trained chefs and have over 13 years of successful catering experience (www.cateringbyashley.com) plus a proven track record in building a business.

Community - I have been a member of the community for over 10 years and I've developed a sense of ownership, pride and awareness of our community. Our passion is making people happy with amazing food and a pleasing presentation. Blackburn's Farm to Table will offer diverse menu items which feature creative combinations of seasonal organic fruits, vegetables and sustainable ingredients.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Refer your family, friends, co-workers and encourage them to support our efforts.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it!

story:
The Uganda Women's Aquaponics Initiative is breaking ground in artisanal development, relying more on skill and human capital than a disruptive influx of cash and technology that is not part of the culture. I have seen a lot of that. Part of what we hope to do is contribute to this low investment high return model that is built more on people and relationships than power and money.

We are seeking limited funding to begin the Uganda Women's Aquaponics Initiative, a project to teach small scale aquaculture and aquaponics to rural women in Uganda. Our focus will be on teaching aquaculture and and aquaponics to young women in High School, and promoting very simple backyard systems that can be easily replicated by older women in the communities we work with. 

The project began as an idea developed with the Uganda Fisheries and Fish Conservation Association (UFFCA), an organization funded by the CDC with the mission of fighting the spread of HIV. UFFCA staff found rural women were sometimes trading sex for fish. We thought that teaching small scale aquaponics to young women in schools would enable them to take the idea home to share with their mothers. Simple aquaponics systems, as seen above, can be put together at very low cost, and help rural women provide nutritious food to their families and potentially a surplus to sell.

From March 18-26 I will be in Uganda with local team members, Mahoro Adeline and Lawrence Migadde, two young and energetic community leaders. Our group is an ad hoc organization with a mission to improve the welfare of rural fishing communities around Uganda's lakes. 
The purpose of this trip is to collect information that we will need in order to apply for multiyear funding for this project, and to formally organize under the the UFFCA, or an appropriate NGO that will take over the administrative component.

I have worked on many Development Bank-funded, capital-intensive projects, and they usually fail. Simplicity and replicability are the watchwords of our efforts. We want to launch a project that will take on a life of its own and become self-supporting. Unlike Development Bank funded projects we are not bringing a one-size fits all solution in search of a problem. This study is to see what is available on the ground in terms of resources and community capacities, to assess needs and the most effective and efficient ways to meet them.

I am a former fisherman, current aquaponics practitioner, and most notably a journalist writing about fisheries and aquaculture. I have worked as a fisheries and aquaculture development consultant for the Passamaquoddy Tribe in Maine, the Yupik corporation of Toksook Bay, Alasaka, and the FAO in Cambodia. I am bringing over forty years experience in fisheries and aquaculture, to the project. My role is to look for new ways to fit existing pieces together and perhaps introduce a few new ideas.

Mahoro Adeline is a farmer in Uganda with a degree in Community Development and Tourism. Through her father, Dr. John Bosco Nizeyi, she is well connected with existing aquaponics and aquaculture projects in Uganda. She has collected most of the preliminary information that has gotten the project this far. It is very likely she will be running this project as it expands

Lawrence Migadde is a commercial fisherman working in one of the rural communities on the shores of Lake Victoria. He is an up and coming leader who I met at Slow Fish in Genoa in May 2017. Lawrence is responsible for breathing new life into the original UFFCA idea and introducing me to Mahoro. He has collected information from potential participants in his community. Lawrence has a great touch with people, he will in many cases be helping set up communications with women in rural communities.

So far I have funded all the research, providing $600 for travel expenses and stipends for Lawrence and Mohoro. I have also put in many hours as a volunteer. 

I would like to raise $5,000 for this on-the-ground study. I will send you our budget and itinerary at your request. We are also happy to learn of any contacts in the region who you would like to introduce us to. 

Our Budget:

All automobile transport expenses: including driver: $1000

Paul's airfare from Cape Town                                              $420

Per diem in Uganda, $60/day x 8                                        $480

Donations ($100) to the organizations farms

and schools we visit, to compensate for their time        $600

Stipends:                                                                         

Mahoro   (project organizing)                                                 $750

Lawrence  (community outreach)                                         $750

Paul            (facilitation and grant writing)                          $1000

Total                                                                                   $5000
story_txt: The Uganda Women's Aquaponics Initiative is breaking ground in artisanal development, relying more on skill and human capital than a disruptive influx of cash and technology that is not part of the culture. I have seen a lot of that. Part of what we hope to do is contribute to this low investment high return model that is built more on people and relationships than power and money.We are seeking limited funding to begin the Uganda Women's Aquaponics Initiative, a project to teach small scale aquaculture and aquaponics to rural women in Uganda. Our focus will be on teaching aquaculture and and aquaponics to young women in High School, and promoting very simple backyard systems that can be easily replicated by older women in the communities we work with. The project began as an idea developed with the Uganda Fisheries and Fish Conservation Association (UFFCA), an organization funded by the CDC with the mission of fighting the spread of HIV. UFFCA staff found rural women were sometimes trading sex for fish. We thought that teaching small scale aquaponics to young women in schools would enable them to take the idea home to share with their mothers. Simple aquaponics systems, as seen above, can be put together at very low cost, and help rural women provide nutritious food to their families and potentially a surplus to sell.From March 18-26 I will be in Uganda with local team members, Mahoro Adeline and Lawrence Migadde, two young and energetic community leaders. Our group is an ad hoc organization with a mission to improve the welfare of rural fishing communities around Uganda's lakes. The purpose of this trip is to collect information that we will need in order to apply for multiyear funding for this project, and to formally organize under the the UFFCA, or an appropriate NGO that will take over the administrative component.I have worked on many Development Bank-funded, capital-intensive projects, and they usually fail. Simplicity and replicability are the watchwords of our efforts. We want to launch a project that will take on a life of its own and become self-supporting. Unlike Development Bank funded projects we are not bringing a one-size fits all solution in search of a problem. This study is to see what is available on the ground in terms of resources and community capacities, to assess needs and the most effective and efficient ways to meet them.I am a former fisherman, current aquaponics practitioner, and most notably a journalist writing about fisheries and aquaculture. I have worked as a fisheries and aquaculture development consultant for the Passamaquoddy Tribe in Maine, the Yupik corporation of Toksook Bay, Alasaka, and the FAO in Cambodia. I am bringing over forty years experience in fisheries and aquaculture, to the project. My role is to look for new ways to fit existing pieces together and perhaps introduce a few new ideas.Mahoro Adeline is a farmer in Uganda with a degree in Community Development and Tourism. Through her father, Dr. John Bosco Nizeyi, she is well connected with existing aquaponics and aquaculture projects in Uganda. She has collected most of the preliminary information that has gotten the project this far. It is very likely she will be running this project as it expandsLawrence Migadde is a commercial fisherman working in one of the rural communities on the shores of Lake Victoria. He is an up and coming leader who I met at Slow Fish in Genoa in May 2017. Lawrence is responsible for breathing new life into the original UFFCA idea and introducing me to Mahoro. He has collected information from potential participants in his community. Lawrence has a great touch with people, he will in many cases be helping set up communications with women in rural communities.So far I have funded all the research, providing $600 for travel expenses and stipends for Lawrence and Mohoro. I have also put in many hours as a volunteer. I would like to raise $5,000 for this on-the-ground study. I will send you our budget and itinerary at your request. We are also happy to learn of any contacts in the region who you would like to introduce us to. Our Budget:All automobile transport expenses: including driver: $1000Paul's airfare from Cape Town                                              $420Per diem in Uganda, $60/day x 8                                        $480Donations ($100) to the organizations farmsand schools we visit, to compensate for their time        $600Stipends:                                                                         Mahoro   (project organizing)                                                 $750Lawrence  (community outreach)                                         $750Paul            (facilitation and grant writing)                          $1000Total                                                                                   $5000

story:
Summary

We're Larry and Jackie from Sylvan Hills farm outside of Menomonie WI, and we've been growing organic produce for 15 years which includes garlic to 5 cooperatives and a small CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) with about 40 - 70 families that purchase a share of veggies weekly from summer through fall. We pick the produce and deliver it within 24hours. Produce can lose 25 to 50 percent of it's nutrition within the first 24 to 48 hours. We also donate surplus produce to the local food shelf (we believe that those who are on the low end of the income stream deserve the highest quality nutritional food they can get.) Our old tractor (Big Joe) died last fall with a hole in the engine block, and we have not had any luck in finding a replacement engine or engine block to repair it. So we need a replacement tractor ASAP. The rush is that it won't be long till we need to plant the garlic and the tractor is used to cut and deliver the mulch to protect the garlic from being winter killed. The reason we want our own tractor is that you have small windows of opportunity to do the things the tractor does, and trying to find someone with one or rent one doesn't work well at all. (We have done this in the past.) Most of the time, they are busy or the tractor is being used by someone else.

We have gardened organically since we were children, and we dreamed of the farm we are on while living in the big Twin Cities for 9 years and before that. We always wanted to be out in the country, working the land. Our previous jobs were in the energy conservation field and the computer printing industry. As technology changes very quickly, the business faded away in the Twin Cities and we needed to find that farm we dreamed of. Be careful of what you ask for, as this farm dropped into our laps only a month after looking, and all the 9 years of dreaming of it brought our farm to reality in September of 2000. We managed to double our CSA each year from the start in 2003 until 2008, when we lost about 3/4 of our memberships due to the housing collapse. We have been able to slowly build the members to about 2/3rds of what it was in 2008. Adding more garlic yearly has helped keep us afloat, but we are at the maximum of our work load now. A big expense, like the tractor we need would REALLY HELP us significantly at this time, when we need the equipment ASAP to mulch the garlic. The tractor is also used to prepare ground and weed control for the CSA.

Song birds have always been important to us, in fact near and dear to our hearts. We avoid cutting any of our grassy hay until after September, since they migrate south anytime between July and September. This allows them to use the hay ground as nesting sites for their babies. The populations of dickcissel, bobolinks (see bobolink video below), and meadow larks are all in decline, so seeing these birds return yearly brings us great joy! We also work around the nests of kill deer birds, which like to build right inside of the garden. It's a spectacular sight to see these babies hopping in a row after Mom (like ducklings) almost immediately after they are hatched. They're a puff ball of white feathers the first few days of their life - cute as the dickens.

Our farm is probably the most important thing in our lives, next to family. We plan to stay here and protect this piece of land as long as we are able, and also to pass it off when we go as designated organic only in a land trust.

You will help us continue to farm and protect the song birds at the same time while allowing our members to continue receiving great food, and protect the planet as well with organic standards. You will be contributing greatly back to the planet, as the United Nations reports, "Small organic farms are THE WAY TO FEED THE WORLD"

We really need your help !! We set our goal at $18,000. The tractor we long for costs $14,900. The  additional funds will be used for the perks we will send plus some additional equipment listed below.  We are giving perks on any contribution as little as a dollar! If we don't reach the goal in our set time, then we may extend the campaign or end it and use the money first to send you perks, and secondly, we can possibly find a used tractor at an auction, but then it's buyer beware as you never know what you get till you run it with a load. If the total is near the goal we may use it for a down payment on the New Holland tractor and continue the campaign with additional perks.

Any money we receive above our goal will be used to purchase additional equipment to protect the soil health and make our job easier.

We are offering perks on any contribution of one dollar or more.

Challenges we will face are the weather and weeds. Which is why we have the additional items we would like to have as they will help deal with weeds (if the weather doesn't cooperate) and let us do what we need when we need to (we have a clay loam soil) and if it rains a lot, it is not possible to use our tillers for weed control as we will make rocks out of it and that's awful hard on the soil biota and the soil itself.  (An old friend used to say that farming is the only legal form of gambling!)

Tractor $14900

Perc's $1000

Shipping and packaging with other miscellaneous costs $1000

Indiegogo charges 5% of what we raise $845

That's a total of $17745 we rounded up to $18000 to cover anything we missed

Additional Equipment we would like to protect the soil and make the job easier

DR Brush cutter $2500

Disc for the tractor $1200

Mower for the tractor $2000

Indiegogo fee $285

Total 23985

Anything we receive above and beyond the extended goal will go to additional equipment. There is always something else that would do a task easier or more efficiently that we have not listed at this time.

Please share this with any one you can think of.

Thank You Very Much

Larry and Jackie
